items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the Faculty Association AFT 157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.20 submission and recommendation: Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of the full load.
	 
Article 9.20 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all Districts assigned service during the college semester for which the y are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.   
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.20 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.

The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees.  Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval.  All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the current bid limit of $83,400 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts and purchase orders for the period of May 10, 2013 through June 9, 2013 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the SSA and EVC is to establish the term and conditions to work collaboratively to provide A Tradition of Caring program.  This program provides education and training to potential and existing kinship and relative caregivers with the goal of preparing each family to become part of the child protection team.
	 
Social Service Agency Responsibilities:  The SSA provides space for classes, evaluates potential clients for program eligibility, and recruits individuals to attend training sessions.
	 
College Responsibilities:  EVC provides specialized and advanced training designed to teach knowledge and skills for kinship and relative caregivers.
	 
Term:  This MOU is effective July 1, 2013 and shall remain in effect until June 30, 2018, unless terminated earlier or otherwise amended.  Delegation of authority expires on June 30, 2018.  
	 
Payment Terms:  There is no exchange of funds related to this MOU.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the MOU between the County of Santa Clara Social Services Agency (SSA) and Evergreen Valley College (EVC) to provide a Tradition of Caring Program
items.item_text: MOU Between County of Santa Clara and EVC to Provide Tradition of Caring Program
items.item_text_raw: 10. MOU Between County of Santa Clara and EVC to Provide Tradition of Caring Program

items.item_details:
This is partnership between SVCF and EVC to provide a foster care support program that will improve college acclimation for a pilot group of foster youth.  The goal is to assist first-year freshmen and at risk sophomores to navigate the demands of college.
	 
The SVCF will provide a program manager, school site supervisor and AmeriCorp Public Ally Interns. 
	 
The college’s YESS Program will provide a site liaison and the FasTrack Program will provide space for tutoring and small group meetings. 
	 
The YES scholarship recipients from SVCF who are EVC students will participate in this pilot program.
	 
Funding
There is no exchange of funds related to this program. 
	 
Term
The agreement shall be in effective September 3, 2013 and remain in effect for 1-3 years.  The agreement may be renewed by mutual agreement.  Either party may terminate the agreement upon written notice.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the agreement between the Silicon Valley Children’s Fund (SVCF) and Evergreen Valley College (EVC) for the college’s participation in a pilot program that provides assistance to foster youth.
items.item_text: MOU Between Silicon Valley Children's Fund and EVC
items.item_text_raw: 11. MOU Between Silicon Valley Children's Fund and EVC

items.item_details: For program year 2012-2013, work2future included Workforce Institute in its WIA Workshop Provider List and awarded all providers in the workshop pool a NTE contract of $600,000 to provide instructor led workshops, online training, and WorkKeys sessions when scheduled by work2future.  On September 11, 2012 the Board of Trustees approved the original workshop pool contract. On June 13, 2013 work2future, City of San Jose increased the pool amount by $205,267.  The total pool amount for FY 2012 -2013 WIA Workshops Contract will be $805,267.

items.item_details:
Following a Request for Qualifications (RFQ) and Request for Proposal (RFP) process, interviews and evaluations were conducted for selection of consultant services related to the land development site adjacent to Evergreen Valley College.  On December 13, 2011 the Board of Trustees approved a consultant contract for Andy Plescia & Co. / Gruen Gruen and Associates Team to assist the District in entering into one or more ground leases for the purpose of developing some or all of the approximately 27 acres of District property which was declared surplus land in 2004.  The land is located at Evergreen Valley College and currently surrounds the retail shopping center at the intersection of San Felipe Road and Yerba Buena Road.  The District desires an economically desirable and aesthetically appealing project that compliments the Evergreen Valley College campus.  The agreement was originally dated January 19, 2012, and was subsequently amended on January 19, 2013 extending the term of the agreement to January 18, 2014.
	 
This contract amendment is to augment the current contract from $75,000 to $95,000 in order to cover unanticipated costs incurred by A. Plescia & Co. and Gruen Gruen + Associates in completing tasks (through issuance of the Request for Proposals (RFP)) over and above the work items set forth in the original Scope of Work and to provide for the implementation of the RFP solicitation, including working with the City of San Jose on land use policy / entitlement issues.
	 
The three primary reasons for the requested budget augmentation are as follows:
	 
1. Consultants attended and participated in a total number of meetings that substantially exceeded the number of meetings called for in the Scope of Work. The majority of these additional meetings related to: 1) meeting with private real estate brokers and developers as part of the predevelopment / due diligence process and 2) working with the Board of Trustee Land Sub-committee from July 2012 through March 2013.
	 
The Scope of Work called for a total of thirteen (13) meetings for these tasks. To date A. Plescia & Co. and Gruen Gruen + Associates either individually or collectively have participated in twenty-one (21) meetings and/or telephone conference calls. This does not include future meetings to review/evaluate proposals submitted in response to the Request for Proposals (RFP) issued on May 17, 2013.
	 
2. The additional meetings with the Board of Trustee Land Sub-committee from July 2012 through March 2013 not only required the additional time for APC / GG+A to attend the subject meetings, but also required them to expend additional time associated with preparation and submittal of written information (agendas, analysis, memorandums / reports, etc.) requested by the Sub-committee members which was not included in the original Scope of Work.
	 
3. APC / GG+A incurred substantial additional time associated with the logistics of finalizing and distributing the Request for Proposals (RFP) document. As part of that process they established an RFP distribution list, prepared the appropriate cover letters for distribution of the RFP, distributed the RFP notice / cover letter to the RFP distribution list, and arranged with the Districtâs procurement staff loading of the RFP on the Districtâs web site. Again these were work items not included in the original Scope of Work.
	 
In addition, in completing the RFP solicitation process it appears that additional effort will be necessary in working with the City of San Jose staff representatives regarding the relationship of City of San Jose land use policies on the type / extent of land use development envisioned for the 27-acre EVC development site.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an amendment, not to exceed $20,000, to the existing agreement with A. Plescia & Co., an independent contractor providing consulting services for the development of District owned land adjacent to Evergreen Valley College.

Among the San Jose City College Measure G:2004 projects approved by the Board was the Multi-Disciplinary & Arts Building. The Multidisciplinary & Arts Building is a design-build project, currently in construction, with a gross maximum price (GPM) established by the Board of Trustees in the amount of $26,671,663.
 
There is no additional cost associated with this change order.  After this change order, project savings is ($578,697.46) and is outlined as follows:

items.item_details:
At the Board meetings held March 13, 2012 and June 12, 2012, the Board was presented information and details by the Program Management team and District legal counsel on the Lease/Leaseback project delivery method.  On July 10, 2012 the Board approved this method for two Measure G-2010 projects.
	 
The Board is asked to approve this Resolution authorizing the Lease-Leaseback Project delivery Method for the Physical Education/Gym Project #122 at San Jose City College.  The success of the method throughout the State and positive response at SJCC and EVC for the already-approved projects has prompted this request.
	 
Lease/Leaseback is a best value based selection process based on a combination of qualifications and fees.  The contractor providing the overall best value to the District will be selected.   The Lease/Leaseback delivery method is considered the best choice to achieve the timely completion of the project in a cost-effective manner.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve utilization of the Lease-Leaseback delivery method for the Physical Education/Gym Project #122 which is a Measure G-2004 Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004 Bond Program: SJCC - Resolution #70913-2 for Lease-Leaseback for Physical Education/Gym Project #122
items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G-2004 Bond Program: SJCC - Resolution #70913-2 for Lease-Leaseback for Physical Education/Gym Project #122

items.item_details:
The Board was presented with the Strategic Goals for a first reading on May 28, 2013. The District Strategic Goals represents the work and consensus over 50 team members representing all constituencies from across the district.  The Strategic Planning Process was vetted through the shared governance process and the Strategic Goals have been approved by the District Council. 
	 
The Strategic Goals are:
1. Student Success
	2. Total Work Environment
	3. Workforce and Economic Development
	4. Organizational Effectiveness and Sustainability
	5. Technology
	6. Communication
Approval of the District Strategic Goals 2013 to 2017 represents a charge to the organization to go about the work of defining and implementing the work of the Strategic Plan.
	 
Background information (attached) includes the District Strategic Goals with Operational Objectives and Tasks.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the District Strategic Goals (attached) for fiscal years 2013-2014 to 2017-2018.
items.item_text: District Strategic Goals 2013 to 2017
items.item_text_raw: 4. District Strategic Goals 2013 to 2017

items.item_details:
On April 12, 2011 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with SunPower Corporation, Systems to provide a photovoltaic solar array at Evergreen Valley College. 
 
	 
As a part of this agreement SunPower was responsible for applying specific seed material to the project site (âhydroseedingâ) to control weeds and to stabilize the site surface soil.  SunPower installed hydroseeding on May 1, 2011.  The material applied by SunPower was disturbed by subsequent SunPower construction operations and did not germinate.  SunPower was notified of this condition and that the District considered the hydroseeding to be incomplete and unacceptable work.  In working to resolve the circumstance it was decided to remove the value of the work from the SunPower contract.  (The District will now have the work performed at the appropriate time later in 2013.)  The District and SunPower have negotiated the deductive value and SunPower submitted a written pricing proposal for documentation purposes (attached).   
	 
	 
Original Contract Amount        $6,096,785
Previous Approved Changes    $2,479,783
Change Order #004                 ($24,000)
Total Contract and Changes     $8,552,568
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Deductive Change Order #004 for SunPower Corporation, Systems in the amount of ($24,000) for the Evergreen Valley College Energy Efficiency Photovoltaic Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC-Energy Efficiency Photovoltaic Project, SunPower Change Order #004
items.item_text_raw: 5. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC-Energy Efficiency Photovoltaic Project, SunPower Change Order #004

items.item_details:
At the Board meetings held March 13, 2012 and June 12, 2012, the Board was presented information and details by the Program Management team and District legal counsel on the Lease/Leaseback project delivery method.  Subsequently, two Measure G-2010 projects have been approved to utilize this method – SJCC Media Arts Center and Career Technical Education project and the EVC South Campus Development project.
	 
The Board is asked to approve Resolution #70913-3 authorizing the Lease-Leaseback Project delivery Method for the Automotive Technology project at Evergreen Valley College.  The success of the method throughout the State and positive response at SJCC and EVC for the already-approved projects has prompted this request.
	 
On May 8, 2012 the Board approved a design contract with Lionakis for the EVC Automotive Technology project.  At that time the intent was to procure the project through the design-bid-build process.  In discussion about using Lease-Leaseback, Lionakis supports the method and has indicated it has no impact to their contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve use of the Resolution #70913-3 Lease-leaseback delivery method for the Evergreen Valley College Automotive Technology Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Resolution #70913-3 EVC Automotive Technology Project – Use of Lease-Leaseback Delivery Method
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Resolution #70913-3 EVC Automotive Technology Project – Use of Lease-Leaseback Delivery Method

items.item_details:
In March 2012 Evergreen Valley College (EVC) and the San Jose Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) approached the Program Manager about replacing the roof on the Gullo Student Center which has had water intrusion issues throughout its lifetime.  In May of 2012, a contract for design services was executed with the specialty design firm Allana Buick and Bers.  
	 
As Allana Buick and Bers performed their assessment on the roof it became apparent that the building had multiple water entry points on the exterior wall system as well.  As a result the replacement of the existing windows, corrugated metal siding, fiber cement boards and upgrades to the below grade waterproofing would be required to have a water tight building.  In addition, the project would now have to be approved by the Division of State Architect.  The construction estimate increased to almost $3 million.
	 
Due to the nature and complexity of the work, general contractors were required to complete a prequalification process that allowed the District to ensure properly-experienced contractors would be bidding the work.  Outreach included notification to the G-2010 Outreach database, District Purchasing database, publication in local newspapers, bid posting via industry publication (The Blue Book), numerous building exchanges, and direct contact with over 60 contractors.  Eight firms responded, and four contractors were prequalified.  The project went out to bid on May 28, 2013.  Two bids were received on June 25, 2013.  The apparent low bidder is Swenson and Associates with a total bid amount of $3,165,000.  The Estimated Cost for the construction was $2,965,000, however the apparent low bid also includes an alternate of $61,000 for DSA-mandated ADA site improvements and $110,000 of allowances to address unforeseen water damage (such as roof plywood repair and unforeseen water damage to the building) for a combined Estimate of $3,136,000.  The total bid amount of $3,165,000 is 0.09% over the Estimated Cost.  Swenson and Associates is the same firm performing the EVC Central Plant and Police Renovation and Upgrade project.  Due to the criticality of the work involved and efficiency of having the same contractor on the Central Plant and Gullo Student Center projects, the Board is asked to approve award of the Gullo Student Center Envelope Upgrade Project to Swenson and Associates in the amount of $3,165,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve award of a contract to Swenson and Associates for the Evergreen Valley College Gullo Student Center Envelope Upgrade Project in the amount of $3,165,000.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC Gullo Student Center Envelope Upgrade Project – Contractor Award
items.item_text_raw: 7. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC Gullo Student Center Envelope Upgrade Project – Contractor Award

items.item_details:
In April 2012 Evergreen Valley College (EVC) and the San Jose Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) approached the Program Manager about upgrading various mechanical, electrical and plumbing (MEP) systems on the Evergreen Valley College Campus.  This work encompasses approximately 60 small upgrades and repairs into a consolidated project.  In February of 2013, a contract for design services was executed with the engineering firm GHD.  
	 
The resulting Phase 1 MEP project was bid on April 23, 2013.  The initial phase of this work was estimated by GHD to have a construction cost of $450,000.  Two bids were received, both over double the engineer’s estimate.  It was subsequently decided by the District to break out the work to have the more critical summer work completed and bid smaller packages directly to specific trades.
	 
One result was to develop the Evergreen Valley College Electrical Upgrade Project, with an engineer’s estimate of $250,000.  In May 2013 the District invited bids from electrical contractors.  During the bid period the project team contacted over 60 contractors including local businesses, minority owned businesses and women owned businesses.  In addition, the Santa Clara & San Benito County Building and Construction Trades Council notified various union-affiliated electrical contractors in the area.  
	 
Despite these efforts a single bid was received on June 18, 2013.  The apparent low bidder is Radiant Electric, Inc. with a total bid amount of $128,000, substantially lower than the engineer’s estimate.  (Radiant Electric is familiar to the District, having performed the EVC 21 kV project over the past Winter Break.)  Due to the criticality of the work involved, the favorable pricing and positive past experience with the low bidder, the Board is asked to approve the contract to Radiant Electric.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve award of a contract to Radiant Electric for the Evergreen Valley College Electrical Upgrade Project in the amount of $128,000.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC Electrical Upgrade Project – Contractor Award
items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC Electrical Upgrade Project – Contractor Award

items.item_details:
The domestic water supply system at San Jose City College contains piping in a mixture of ages and conditions.  The college has several buildings where water cannot be turned off without affecting large portions of the campus, and there are some water lines original to the campus which are in poor condition. An effort was undertaken beginning in September 2012 to locate and map the water lines on the SJCC campus, and to assess and identify where repairs were needed.  At the request of the College, the Board approved a Project Assignment Amendment with Sandis Engineers in April 2013 to provide design, engineering and construction phase administration services addressing the issues discovered during assessment and programming.  The design calls for replacement of aged water lines, replacement of broken water valves, and installation of isolation valves to allow better control over the water system.  This project will help ensure the reliability of the water system on the San Jose City College Campus and reduce future outages and leaks.
	 
A public bidding process for contractors was conducted between June 3, 2013 and June 21, 2013.  The project was posted on the Districtâs purchasing website, advertised in local papers on June 4th, June 11th and published at 20 local buildersâ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 100 contractors.  Bids were opened at 3 pm on June 21, 2013.  Based on the evaluation of bid prices and required documentation, it was determined that Preston Pipelines was the apparent lowest responsible bidder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a construction contract to Preston Pipelines in the amount of $201,000 for the San Jose City College Water System Repairs Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: SJCC Water System Repairs Project
items.item_text_raw: 9. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: SJCC Water System Repairs Project

items.item_details:
As has been discussed with the Board previously, the Acacia and Roble Complexes are located within a seismic fault zone that was recently determined to be active.  As required by law, the District notified the State Chancellor's Office of this issue in October 2011 and has been actively engaged in the planning activities that will result in the removal and replacement of these buildings out of the fault zone.  
	 
The space provided by the Cluster Acacia and Cluster Roble will be replaced under three projects currently represented on the Measure G-2010 Bond Project List: South Campus Development, Automotive Technology and Engineering & Applied Technology.  The District does, however, have the opportunity and requirement to apply to the State for funding support for a component of this program due to the seismic issue.  As such, an Initial Project Proposal (IPP) for Acacia - Roble Replacement (Engineering & Applied Technology) for the 2015-16 funding year was submitted to the State Chancellor's Office in July of 2012.  The IPP was approved by the Chancellor’s Office thus allowing the District to proceed with a Final Project Proposal.  The Final Project Proposal requests the State to support 50% of the budget for the demolition of Roble and replacement of space represented by the project referred to as Engineering & Applied Technology on the Measure G-2010 Master Bond Project List.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2015 Final Project Proposal for the Evergreen Valley College Engineering & Applied Technology project (formerly known as the Acacia - Roble Replacement) for submission to the State Chancellor's Office for consideration for State funding in the 2015 funding year.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: 2015 Final Project Proposal for the Engineering & Applied Technology Building at Evergreen Valley College
items.item_text_raw: 10. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: 2015 Final Project Proposal for the Engineering & Applied Technology Building at Evergreen Valley College

items.item_details:
At the Board meetings held March 13, 2012 and June 12, 2012, the Board was presented information and details by the Program Management team and District legal counsel on the Lease/Leaseback (LLB) project delivery method.  Subsequently the EVC South Campus Development project has been approved to utilize this method and Blach Construction (Blach) has been approved as the LLB Contractor.
	 
South Campus is a $41 million project housing multi-discipline science laboratories, mathematics labs and classrooms, social science programs, fitness center and faculty offices.  The College and Program Manager, as part of the contractor selection process, identified utilizing design-assist methods to involve the subcontractors in specific trades.  Design-assist is a method that brings specific trade subcontractors to the design process, taking advantage of their knowledge and expertise to advise on areas to save cost, and to advise on materials, methods and coordination specific to their trade.  This results in decisions being made during the design that are directly relevant to developing the most cost-effective and constructible building.  The Subcontractors were prequalified based on relevant criteria and bid competitively, providing a guaranteed maximum price to the LLB Contractor, with the lowest confirmed bidder being selected.  The trade subcontract terms allow costs during the design phase to be recouped should the project be cancelled.  The District’s contract with Blach allows for payment to the LLB Contractor “for all work provided to the date of termination.”  (The full LLB Contract with Blach is attached for reference.) Thus, should the project be cancelled Blach could seek reimbursement for these trade subcontractor design phase expenses from the District as “work provided”.  However, if the project proceeds, the costs become part of the construction phase and are paid upon acceptance of the LLB Contractor Guaranteed Maximum Price.  This concept is normal in construction contracts where it is important to receive the benefit of specific trades during the design phase yet the intent is to continue the effort into the construction phase.  The project budget has anticipated these costs, which would be as follows:
Exterior Envelope (Royal Glass) - $646,356  (The scope of this effort is more extensive than other trades because it includes material mock ups, and complete detailed shop drawings and calculations that will expedite the Division of State Architect approval process.)
 
HVAC/Mechanical Systems (AGC Mechanical) - $93,000
Plumbing Systems (Hellwig Plumbing) - $42,000
Electrical Systems (Rosendin Electric) - $76,000
	 
In summary, the Board is asked to recognize that the award of design-assist trade contracts as listed above by the LLB Contractor commits them to subcontracts that, in the event of contract termination, would have the LLB Contractor seek compensation for costs up to the amount of $857,356 as part of its “work provided” under its contract terms.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve use of Design-Assist Subcontracts through Blach Construction consistent with the Lease-leaseback delivery method for the Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC South Campus – Use of Design-Assist Trades Agreements
items.item_text_raw: 11. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC South Campus – Use of Design-Assist Trades Agreements

items.item_details:
The old Boiler Plant will be re-purposed to accommodate the offices and storage of Custodial and Grounds.  Custodial equipment and storage from the East portion of Building 200 will be relocated to the Boiler Plant. Grounds equipment will move from its current location to what is now the Batting Cages. 
	 
This is a precursor to the renovation of buildings 100 and 200. This will free up needed swing space for the wing renovations, and will consolidate grounds and custodial, as well as their storage and equipment, into a central location on campus.
	 
In March 2013, the Board approved a Project Assignment Amendment with Hibser Yamauchi Architects to provide design and construction phase administration services for the project.  Since March 2013, HY Architects has met regularly with the Design Committee made up of SJCC administration and staff members to establish the Collegeâs needs, and refine the project design.  The Design Committee is pleased with the design.
	 
A public bidding process for contractors was conducted between June 17, 2013 and July 2, 2013.  The project was advertised in local papers on June 18th, June 25th and published at 15 local buildersâ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 55 contractors.  A mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on June 26, 2013 with approximately 12 interested contractors and subcontractors.  Bids were opened at 3 p.m. on July 2, 2013.  Based on the evaluation of bid prices and required documentation, it was determined that Omni Construction Services, Inc. was the apparent lowest responsible bidder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a contract to Omni Construction Services, Inc. in the amount of $398,000 for the San Jose City College Repurpose Boiler Plant Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: SJCC Repurpose Boiler Plant Project
items.item_text_raw: 12. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: SJCC Repurpose Boiler Plant Project

items.item_details:
Beginning in 2001 with the construction of the Central Plant, San Jose City College has been extending new underground electrical, telecommunications, gas, heating and cooling water to buildings on campus.  Utilities have been extended in several phases as new buildings are built, or old buildings remodeled.  The SJCC Utility Extension project will continue connecting additional existing buildings on the SJCC campus to the modern central plant, as well as prepare connections to future new buildings.  This project prepares the way for the Media Arts Center and Career Technology Education projects by bringing modern & reliable electrical, gas, heating & cooling water, telecommunications and fire alarm systems to a part of campus which is currently served by systems that date back to the 1950’s.  These systems are no longer reliable or efficient, and many are fed from the 300 Wing Building, which is scheduled for demolition in summer 2014.  This project is necessary in order to provide reliable utility infrastructure, as well as allow the renovation of the 100 & 200 buildings for Career Technology, and the construction of the Media Arts Center.
	 
This project will also provide an emergency generator to support the campus MDF (Main Distribution Frame), which is the hub of all telecommunications and data on campus, as well as the emergency operations center.  The campus MDF and emergency operations center currently do not have a generator, and are vulnerable in the event of power outage.  The generator will ensure that the campus MDF continues to operate without loss of data, can continue to provide critical telecommunications, and that the emergency operations center can remain operational even during a power outage. 
	 
At the January 8, 2013 Board meeting, the Board approved a Project Assignment Amendment with Salas O’Brien Engineers to provide design & engineering services for the project.  As the campus engineer providing design for many other utility projects including the central plant, Salas O’Brien is very familiar with the SJCC Campus, its current infrastructure and its needs.  Since January they have met with College and District Staff, facilities personnel, and the design teams for other campus projects in order to develop the project design. 
	 
A public bidding process for contractors was conducted between June 17, 2013 and July 2, 2013.  The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers on June 18th, June 25th and published at 20 local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 100 contractors.  Bids were opened at 2 p.m. on July 2, 2013.  Based on the evaluation of bid prices and required documentation, it was determined that JKL Construction Services was the apparent lowest responsible bidder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a construction contract to JKL Construction Services in the amount of $2,880,567 for the San Jose City College Utility Extension Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: SJCC Utility Extension Project
items.item_text_raw: 13. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: SJCC Utility Extension Project

items.item_details:
The District is required to submit, on an annual basis, a Five Year Capital Construction Plan to the State Chancellor's Office that summarizes current and proposed capital outlay projects.  This plan includes all state and locally funded capital construction projects the District will be working on within the next five years.  This plan is required to be adopted by the Board of Trustees.
	 
The Plan is being presented to the Board of Trustees as a final document for approval. Minor edits may be made to the Plan at the request of the State Chancellor’s Office once submitted to the State.
	 
Attachments:    
Five‐Year Plan ‐ Excerpt from State Chancellor’s Office Facilities Planning Manual
San Jose Evergreen Master Plan Summary with Five‐Year Plan
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the 2015 ‐ 2019 Five Year Construction Plan as required by the State Chancellor's Office as a provision under Community College Construction Act (California Education Code Section 81800).

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Program Specialist layoff in Student Services at San Jose City College is due to lack of funding.  The majority of funding, approximately 67%, came from Matriculation.  Under the Student Success and Support Program initiative, matriculation funding can only be used for assessment, orientation, and counseling - educational planning and follow-up.  In addition, there are no funding resources available to support the remaining 33% of this position
	 
	 
Therefore, the Chancellor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 070913-6 Classified layoff due to lack of funds/lack of work and authorize District representatives to provide all affected employees with a sixty (60) day notice of layoff.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adpot Resolution No. 070913-6 Classified layoff due to lack of funds/lack of work as submitted.

items.item_details: The HVAC, FMT and Laser departments at San Jose City College are currently located in the 100 and 200 Wings buildings that were outdated, inadequate, and in serious disrepair.   The plans are underway to renovate classrooms and laboratories for these programs including purchase of new equipment.  The faculty from CTE areas will be presenting the program highlights, classroom and lab updates, industry trends including the future for new energy efficiency technologies.  The presentation includes the facilities impact on student learning, certificate and degree programs and the local employer needs in the tri-county area.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Education Code 84040.3, each organization that is described in Section 501(c)3 of the Internal Revenue Code that is recognized by the governing board of a community college district as having a formal relationship with and that is working on behalf of the district or a community college within the district shall file a copy of its audited financial report for the previous fiscal year with the governing board on or before April 1 of each year.
	 
The Foundation Board of Directors took action to receive the audited financial statements for the years ending June 30, 2011 and 2012; the Management Recommendation Letter; and the response to the Management Recommendation Letter at their meeting of June 27, 2013.  Accordingly, the above-referenced reports for the San Jose Evergreen Community College District Foundation are provided for the Board of Trustees' information.
